at.ac.tuwien.infosys.g2021.intf

Class TimeControl

  • java.lang.Object
    • at.ac.tuwien.infosys.g2021.intf.TimeControl

  • public class TimeControl
extends java.lang.Object
    This class offers a time triggered retrieval of all the buffer values. Instances of this class can be created with the DataPoint.getTimeControl() method. The delay between value retrievals is at least 100 milliseconds.
    See Also:
    DataPoint.getTimeControl()

      • getResultQueue

        public java.util.concurrent.BlockingQueue<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,SimpleData>> getResultQueue()
        Returns the queue, where buffer data is put into.
        Returns:
        the result queue, which is never null

      • get

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,SimpleData> get()
                                               throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Retrieves the eldest data of the result queue, waiting if necessary until data becomes available.
        Returns:
        the eldest data retrieved from the data point
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the calling thread is interrupted while waiting

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the Timer, causing it to start retrieving buffer data.
        See Also:
        stop()

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Returns true if the Timer is running.
        Returns:
        true if the Timer is running.
        See Also:
        start()

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the Timer, causing it to stop retrieving buffer data.
        See Also:
        start()

      • restart

        public void restart()
        Restarts the Timer, clearing the result queue und start data retrieval with its initial delay.

      • getInitialDelay

        public int getInitialDelay()
        Returns the initial delay of the Timer in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        the initial delay of the Timer in milliseconds.

      • setInitialDelay

        public void setInitialDelay(int initialDelay)
        Set the initial delay of the Timer in milliseconds. This method has no effect to the current delay of a running Timer.
        Parameters:
        initialDelay - the initial delay of the Timer in milliseconds.

      • getDelay

        public int getDelay()
        Returns the delay between two retrievals of the Timer in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        the delay between two retrievals of the Timer in milliseconds.

      • setDelay

        public void setDelay(int delay)
        Set the delay between two retrievals of the Timer in milliseconds. This method has no effect to the current delay of a running Timer.
        Parameters:
        delay - the delay of the Timer in milliseconds.

      • getCount

        public int getCount()
        Gets the number of retrievals after the Timer will stop. The result is 0, if there is no limit of retrievals.
        Returns:
        the number of the retrievals.

      • setCount

        public void setCount(int count)
        Sets the number of retrievals after the Timer will stop. A value <= 0 means, that no limit of retrievals exists and the timer must not stop automatically. This method has no effect to the current count of a running Timer.
        Parameters:
        count - the number of the retrievals.

      • getRemaining

        public int getRemaining()
        Gets the number of remaining retrievals after a the running Timer will stop automatically. The result is 0, if the timer isn't running or there is no limit of retrievals.
        Returns:
        the remaining number of the retrievals.
